How to add key events to dynamically created element ?
How to attach key events to dynamically created element in backbone view ?

You can see an example in the 2.4.3 Todo View. If you notice in the code example, there is a property called 'events' where you can bind any kind of events to functions, including key events. The convention is the following:

'<event_name> <class or="" id="">': <function name="">

Examples:
'keypress #new-todo': 'createTodoOnEnter'
'keydown #new-todo': 'doSomething'
"click .icon": "open"
"dblclick" : "open"

You can see an example in the 2.4.3 Todo View. If you notice in the code example, there is a property called 'events' where you can bind any kind of events to functions, including key events. The convention is the following:

'{{event_name}} {{class_name_or_id}}': {{function_name}}

Examples:
'keypress #new-todo': 'createTodoOnEnter'
'keydown #new-todo': 'doSomething'
"click .icon": "open"
"dblclick" : "open"

You can attach events to dynamically created elements by creating them with the proper class or id. For instance, in the code example above, every element created with the #new-todo class will listen for the keypress event.

If msmpeng.exe continues to restart itself you can try the following. <right click=""> on the application in the services window, <left click=""> on "properties", <right click=""> on "recovery" and set the "failure" boxes to "take no action". Just thought I'd throw this up for anyone else learning underscore with a rails app.... Thanks for the excellent tutorial!

Rails attempts to parse Underscore's <%- %>. Use the following to change underscore's settings to Mustache's style {{= }} and {{ }}. Modify your local underscore settings using the following.

_.templateSettings = {
interpolate: /\{\{\=(.+?)\}\}/g,
evaluate: /\{\{(.+?)\}\}/g
};

Very small bug, when you update a to-do and enter an empty string, the new empty string will not be saved, which is good, but if you'll double-click again on the same to-do, the input now will be empty instead of containing the to-do text.

There is more than one way to fix it. I modified the close function to be:

close: function(){
var value = this.input.val().trim();
if(value) {
this.model.save({title: value});
}
else{
this.input.val(this.model.get('title'));
}
this.$el.removeClass('editing');
},

<html>

<head>

<meta charset="UTF-8">

<meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge,chrome=1">

<title>To-do App in Backbone.js</title>

<style type="text/css">

/* Hides bullet points from todo list */

#todoapp ul {

list-style-type: none;

}

</style>

</head>

<body>

<section id="todoapp">

<header id="header">

<h1>Todos</h1>

<input id="new-todo" placeholder="What needs to be done?" autofocus="">

</header>

<section id="main">

<ul id="todo-list"></ul>

</section>

</section>

<script type="text/template" id="item-template">

<div class="view">

<input class="toggle" type="checkbox">

<label><%- title %></label>

</div>

</script>

<script src="http://ajax.googleapis.com/..." type="text/javascript"></script>

<script src="http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com..." type="text/javascript"></script>

<script src="http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com..." type="text/javascript"></script>

<script src="http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com..." type="text/javascript"></script>

<script type="text/javascript">

var app = {}; // create namespace for our app

//--------------Models--------------

app.Todo = Backbone.Model.extend({

defaults: {

title: '',

completed: false

}

});

//-------------- Collections --------------

app.TodoList = Backbone.Collection.extend({

model: app.Todo,

localStorage: new Store("backbone-todo")

});

// instance of the Collection

app.todoList = new app.TodoList();

//-------------- Views --------------

// renders individual todo items list (li)

app.TodoView = Backbone.View.extend({

tagName: 'li',

template: _.template($('#item-template').html()),

render: function(){

this.$el.html(this.template(this.model.toJSON()));

return this; // enable chained calls

}

});

// renders the full list of todo items calling TodoView for each one.

app.AppView = Backbone.View.extend({

el: '#todoapp',

initialize: function () {

this.input = this.$('#new-todo');

app.todoList.on('add', this.addAll, this);

app.todoList.on('reset', this.addAll, this);

app.todoList.fetch(); // Loads list from local storage

},

events: {

'keypress #new-todo': 'createTodoOnEnter'

},

createTodoOnEnter: function(e){

if ( e.which !== 13 || !this.input.val().trim() ) { // ENTER_KEY = 13

return;

}

app.todoList.create(this.newAttributes());

this.input.val(''); // clean input box

},

addOne: function(todo){

var view = new app.TodoView({model: todo});

$('#todo-list').append(view.render().el);

},

addAll: function(){

this.$('#todo-list').html(''); // clean the todo list

app.todoList.each(this.addOne, this);

},

newAttributes: function(){

return {

title: this.input.val().trim(),

completed: false

}

}

});

//-------------- Initializers --------------

app.appView = new app.AppView();

</script>

</body>

</html>

},

Seems something is missing from these instructions...

pi@RASPI2 ~/shairport $ sudo update-rc.d airplay defaults
update-rc.d: using dependency based boot sequencing
insserv: warning: script 'airplay' missing LSB tags and overrides
insserv: warning: script 'mathkernel' missing LSB tags and overrides

A bit of research and I got it working by doing the following.
(Now my AirPi starts automatically on boot)

STEP 1.
Edit /etc/init.d/airplay to include the following...
### BEGIN INIT INFO

# Provides: airplay
# Required-Start:
# Required-Stop:
# Should-Start:
# Default-Start: 2 3 4 5
# Default-Stop: 0 1 6
### END INIT INFO
-- and for me, I had to change the path to shairport as follows...
#/usr/local/bin/shairport -a "AirPi"
/home/pi/shairport/shairport -a "AirPi"

STEP 2.
-- edit /etc/init.d/mathkernel to include the following...
### BEGIN INIT INFO

# Provides: mathkernel
# Required-Start:
# Required-Stop:
# Should-Start:
# Default-Start:
# Default-Stop:
### END INIT INFO

STEP 3.
--set permissions on mathkernel, just like you did with airplay
sudo chmod a+x /etc/init.d/mathkernel

It looks like in 0.9.2, if you passed an empty route to the filter, the params value would be an empty space. In 1.1.2, the empty route creates a null params value. Nulls don't have a trim() function, so it throws an error. You can correct it by replacing the window.filter assignment to:

window.filter = params && params.trim ? params.trim() : '';

In this article, Im explaining about Backbone.js.

A Single-Page Application (SPA), also known as Single-Page Interface (SPI), is a web application or web site that fits on a single web page with the goal of providing a more fluid user experience similar to a desktop application.

Backbone.js is a lightweight JavaScript library that adds structure to your client-side code. Developers commonly use libraries like Backbone.js to create single-page applications (SPAs). SPAs are web applications that load into the browser and then react to data changes on the client side without requiring complete page refreshes from the server.

Model:

A Model in backbone consists of the connected data for the web application. It also contains the connection among the data. It contains the interactive data.

View:

The view is the user interface but in backbone it is not only the view but also a controller for connecting the model to the data interaction.

Collection:

Collections are the set of models, we create the collection by extending the Backbone.Collection. While creating the collection we want to pass the property that specifies the specific model that the collection will hold.

The problem is that you must be triggering the 'reset' even on your todoList collection BEFORE you even registered for that event. To solve this, you must start dispatching routes AFTER you have initialized your app view (or wherever you register for 'reset' event). Therefore, in this tutorial's context, moving ' Backbone.history.start();' to the end, i.e. after appView initialization, will solve the issue.

> The Model centralizes the business logic

This is very bad idea and common mistake. Model should only represent data. I would say it's much better to move business logic apart from both models and controllers. For example check rails_workflow gem ( http://github.com/madzhuga/... ) - it allows to configure processes containing operations and split business logic in separate layer. Also please notice that it allows not just build processes (which is only part of it) but also to trace and manage processes, checking those which fails, restart them etc. Business logic should be not just set of 'service' classes or callback.

Good question. For handling Web sockets you need sticky connections. This means that you cannot longer route request to next available server. Instead, you have to assign client's requests to the same Web server every time. On the other side, Web servers can use any messaging solution like rabbitmq. With pubsub you can push updates from the microservices to Web server. Using socketIO, for instance, the client/browser can subscribe to what events they want to listen. All in all, microservices push all their messages to Web server, clients subscribe to what messages' "channel" they want to listen to. Finally, clients get updated when messages come

In the "with ES6, the caller selects only the data they need:", people unfamiliar with ES6 won't understand the syntax there, as the concept of "you can compact { a: a } to just { a }" isn't explicitly mentioned, nor is there an ES5 equivalent that shows that this is actually return { left: ..., top: ..., right: ..., bottom: ... }, which makes it clearer that there's nothing magical going on, we're simply still destructuring a regular object, not some object-bypassing-syntax.
Yeah, for this example sake we are ignoring `format` on purpose and focusing the attention on the params

Yes, ES6 took some things from Coffeescript such as the fat arrow functions (=>). Not thin arrow (->) though; The """ of CoffeeScript is ` on ES6; String interpolation #{} is ${} on ES6. And so on...
Wait for it ;)

One thing they didn't quite finish taking from coffeescript was class. You can't have static class properties in es6. People tend to clump static props below their es6 classes as a result. Fat arrow is also better in coffeescript when combined with class because the bindings get compiled into the constructor where as with es6 you still find yourself calling bind all over the place.

Also the ?. operator... That thing is so awesome. Made its way into Ruby as &. operator

Good article but I think the hoisting example this would have shown the hoisting in a clearer way:

let x = 'global scope' 

function test (inner) {
  let x = 'top of function'

  if (inner) {
    let x = 'inside if statement'
    return x
  }

  return x
}

test(false)
test (true)

var x = 'global'

function test(inner) {
  var x = 'top of function'

  if (inner) {
    x = 'inside if statement'
    return x
  }

  return x
}

test(false)
test(true)

This example shows that x is not leaked into the global (window) scope.

Also about const, you can change the properties of an object with it:

const obj = {
  name: 'Tony',
  age: 33,
  occupation: 'JavaScript developer',
  greeting() {
    return `${this.name} is ${this.age} and works as a ${this.occupation}`
  }
}

obj.greeting();

obj.name = 'Anthony';
obj.greeting();
use Babel and you'll be all set.

this.activeTasks = this.todos.filter(todo => !todo.isDone).length; counts active tasks

Slightly larger bug.
Ids are not added to new tasks so if you add 2 tasks and then update one, the unupdated task gets replaced by the one that is updated. Deleteing one will get both.

to each of the functions in todo.components.ts that affected the number of tasks.

how to use

const { ipcRenderer } = require('electron');

in normal js which is running node?
That was awesome, thank you very much
You are welcome!

This is using ES6 syntax. It is equivalent to having:

const electron = require('electron');
const ipcRenderer = electron. ipcRenderer;

Or

const ipcRenderer = require('electron'). ipcRenderer;

Then using the destructing assignment you get:

const { ipcRenderer } = require('electron');

You can learn more about it on this blog post: http://adrianmejia.com/blog...

Hey, im using a similar scenario.
I'm using some git repos for automatic configuration versioning.
Now
after adding my third cron git auto commit job on the same server with
the same "auto-commit" user - git seems to mixup the repositorys.
I think thats because one script adds the unstaged / changed files and the next one uses commit in the same second..
To
prevent this I've to configure the scripts with a fixed execution time,
but that could be better... eg.: one of my archive repos is for more
than 100 network switches/routers.
They push their config after a change directly over scp on my job server.
There is a every 1 minute job that looks on the local folder and checks for a specific file suffix.
If
there is a file with this suffix, im using sed to remove some lines
like timestamps and overwrite the last config file for this device.
than i check with git if there are changes to commit and if then do so.

What
would be the best option to difference this tasks, running them with
sepperate users? fixed execution times? is there a option to say "git
add. -repository...?" or something like this?

The balance factor is normally an enumeration - see http://uuindouus.net/Html/E....

Yes, that's another way to implement it. The code here can be easily translated it to the enumeration "LeftHigh", "Balanced", "RightHigh". Where "LeftHigh" is if balanceFactor is > 1, "Balanced" if balance factor is in between -1 and 1 and "RightHigh" is balance factor is < -1

if you calculate the balance factor by descending the tree the performanse goes to poo.
see http://rosettacode.org/wiki.... You never need to descend the tree to

feel free to use any of the code mentioned in http://www.rosettacode.org/....
